data.text: English, Scottish, and Irish: generally a nickname referring to the color of the hair or complexion, Middle English br(o)un, from Old English brÅ«n or Old French brun. This word is occasionally found in Old French, Middle English and Old Norse as a personal name or byname (Middle English personal name Brun, Broun, ancient Germanic Bruno, Old English BrÅ«n, or possibly Old Norse BrÃºnn or BrÃºni). Brun- was also an ancient Germanic name-forming element. Some instances of Old English BrÅ«n as a personal name may therefore be short forms of compound names such as BrÅ«ngar, BrÅ«nwine, etc. As a Scottish and Irish name, it sometimes represents a translation of Gaelic Donn (see below). Brown (including in the senses below) is the fourth most frequent surname in the US. It is also very common among African Americans and Native Americans (see also 5 below).
